15.heading: Tamaki, Jillian, 1980-
15.title: Skim
15.author: words by Mariko Tamaki ; drawings by Jillian Tamaki.
notes: Summary (from OCLC): "Skim" (Kimberly Keiko Cameron) is a not-slim would-be Wiccan goth who goes to a private girls' school. When her classmate Katie is dumped by her boyfriend, who then kills himself, the entire school goes into mourning overdrive. The popular clique stars a club to boost school spirit, but Skim sinks into an ever-deepening depression.

18.heading: Tamakoshi, Hiroyuki.
18.title: Boys Be Second Season

19.heading: Tamakoshi, Hiroyuki.
19.title: Gacha Gacha
19.author: Hiroyuki Tamakoshi ; translated and adapted by David Ury.
notes: Translation of: Gachagacha.
"Del Rey."

Summary (from OCLC): Lately, Kouhei can't get his friend Kurara out of his mind. Even though he has known her since elementary school, all of a sudden, ever since she came back from summer vacation, he has been crushing on her hard. But something is different about Kurara-she is acting very oddly. Sometimes she seems wholesome, pure, and innocent, and at other times she is extremely forward and unabashed. Kouhei soon learns that Kurara has multiple personalities-and decides to help her keep her secret from their classmates. But Kouhei finds himself struggling between helping Kurara as a friend and trying to win her heart, which is a challenge, since she has many!
"Mature content."

53.heading: Tamburini, Stefano.
53.title: "Bololy Folly"
53.author: art by Liberatore ; written by Stefano Tamburini
53.appears_in: p. 43-49 in Video Clips (New York : Catalan Communicatons, 1985).
notes: Summary: A small atomic bomb was dropped on Pisa, and as a result many "handicapped children" were born. The handicap has the appearance of Down's Syndrome. A new invention that plugs into the brain helps them function, and the dictator of Italy is one example. He has decreed that all citizens must walk the streets naked with their hands on their heads starting in April.
Data from Grand Comic-Book Database.

55.heading: Tamburini, Stefano.
55.title: "E.M.P.S."
55.author: art by Liberatore ; written by Stefano Tamburini
55.appears_in: p. 25-31 in Video Clips (New York : Catalan Communicatons, 1985).
notes: Summary: Comrade 391 goes to the Erotic Management for People's Socialism clinic to be analyzed. The session is a violent homosexual encounter in which the patient uses a whip and the therapist (a "Stalinist-Reichian") wears a Superman suit.
This story appears in Spanish as "E.M.P.E." in El Víbora, no. 26 (1982).

56.title: "Earth Versus Saturn"
56.author: art by Liberatore ; written by Stefano Tamburini
56.appears_in: p. 15-24 in Video Clips (New York : Catalan Communicatons, 1985) ; also appears in 15 Years of Heavy Metal (Heavy Metal Special ; v. 6, no. 4)
notes: Summary: Saturnians begin an invasion of Earth at a cafe near Naples.

58.heading: Tamburini, Stefano.
58.title: "Tiamotti!"
58.author: art by Liberatore ; written by Stefano Tamburini
58.appears_in: p. 61-67 in Video Clips (New York : Catalan Communicatons, 1985).
notes: Summary: Psychic probes around the city detect subversive thoughts, so that the thinkers can be eliminated. Each probe is connected to a policeman, who is welded to a machine gun. The policemen can only shoot if the probe detects mental subversion, however, and the protagonists try to defeat the system by not thinking about what they are doing.

75.heading: Tamil Classics.
75.title: "Kannagi : Her Love Conquers All"
75.author: script, Lalitha Raghupati ; illustrations, Varnam ; editor, Anant Pai
75.appears_in: p. 1-32 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 666 (1975, 2010 printing).
notes: (Indian Classics)

Summary from back cover: "Life is unfair: the virtuous Kannagi deserves a loving husband but selfish beauties and foolish kings combine to rob her of happiness. Her patience snaps, eventually. Pure in her love, this gentle woman is transformed into an avenging angel, raining death and doom on all her foes, until the gods are forced to intervene. Ilango Adigal's Tamil classic, Shilappadikaram, presents life with all its flaws, but also with hope."

76.heading: Tamil Nadu.
76.title: "Ramanuja : a Great Vaishnava Saint"
76.author: script, Chakravarti Anantachar ; illustrations, S
76.appears_in: Nageswara Rao ; editor, Anant Pai. p. 1-31 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 715 (1974, 2010 printing).
notes: (Visionaries)

Summary from back cover: "Ramanuja (AD 1017-1137) lived for 120 years, traversing the land from Tamil Nadu to Kashmir. People flocked to him to understand his unusual message: the path to ultimate bliss. High caste or low, wealthy or poor, Ramanuja turned no one away. The great Acharya who wrote scholarly commentaries on sacred texts like the Bhagavad Gita was first and foremost a simple-hearted devotee. He inspired the Bhakti movement that spread throughout the country."

77.heading: Tamil Nadu.
77.title: "Subramania Bharati : the Tamil Voice of Freedom"
77.author: script, Kalvi Gopalakrishnan & Luis Fernandes ; illustratons, Dilip Kadam ; editor, Anant Pai
77.appears_in: p. 1-32 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 708 (1982, 2010 printing).
notes: (Visionaries)

Summary from back cover: "Teacher, writer, poet and a rebel, Subramania Bharati used the power of his pen to make the mighty British Raj tremble. His songs were sung by all sections of peole in Tamil Nadu, during mass gatherings and Satyagrahas. Revered as the father of modern Tamil renaissance, his heart beat for one India. He was aptly called Bharati, a title bestowed on him for his patriotic songs."

78.heading: Tamil Renaissance.
78.title: "Subramania Bharati : the Tamil Voice of Freedom"
78.author: script, Kalvi Gopalakrishnan & Luis Fernandes ; illustratons, Dilip Kadam ; editor, Anant Pai
78.appears_in: p. 1-32 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 708 (1982, 2010 printing).
notes: (Visionaries)

Summary from back cover: "Teacher, writer, poet and a rebel, Subramania Bharati used the power of his pen to make the mighty British Raj tremble. His songs were sung by all sections of peole in Tamil Nadu, during mass gatherings and Satyagrahas. Revered as the father of modern Tamil renaissance, his heart beat for one India. He was aptly called Bharati, a title bestowed on him for his patriotic songs."

79.heading: Tamil Speakers.
79.title: "Karttikeya : a Son of Shiva"
79.author: script: Pradip Bhattacharya & Meera Ugra ; artworks: C
79.appears_in: M. Vitankar. 30 p. in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 529 (1981, 1997 printing).
notes: (Epics & Mythology)

Summary from back cover: "The Puranas describe Karttikeye, a son of Shiva, as the commander-in-chief of the celestial army. He is also known as Subrahmanya, Skanda, Guha and Kumara. To the Tamil-speaking people he is Murugan. The six-headed, twelve-armed Karttikeya seated on a peacock is the symbol of youth, beauty, valour and supreme wisdom."
Subtitle, series and summary from 2010 printing.

80.heading: Tamil Stories.
80.title: "The Fool's Disciples : Tales of Sense and Nonsense"
80.author: script, Indira Ananthakrishnan and Prathibha N
80.appears_in: G. ; illustrations, Ram Waeerkar ; editor, Anant Pai. p. 1-30 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 713 (1982, 2009 printing).
notes: (Fables & Humour)

Summary from back cover: "Laugh your head off at the unbelievably foolish antics of Paramartha and his disciples, but you'll find, surprisingly, that you are always on their side. Their kindly, simple ways have had a fan following since the 17th century, when the tales were concocted by an Italian priest who settled in Madurai. In this Tamil work, the author hits upon a happy combination of sound advice and rollicking humour."

81.heading: The Tamil Voice of Freedom.
81.title: "Subramania Bharati : the Tamil Voice of Freedom"
81.author: script, Kalvi Gopalakrishnan & Luis Fernandes ; illustratons, Dilip Kadam ; editor, Anant Pai

Summary from back cover: "Teacher, writer, poet and a rebel, Subramania Bharati used the power of his pen to make the mighty British Raj tremble. His songs were sung by all sections of peole in Tamil Nadu, during mass gatherings and Satyagrahas. Revered as the father of modern Tamil renaissance, his heart beat for one India. He was aptly called Bharati, a title bestowed on him for his patriotic songs."

92.heading: Taming.
92.title: "Ganga : the Divine Beauty"
92.author: script, Lakshmi Seshadri ; artwork, S
92.appears_in: S. Havaldar. 30 p. in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 515 (1975, 1998 printing).
notes: (Epics & Mythology)

Summary from back cover: "Ganga's cleansing waters were urgently needed on Earth. But, the dauntless daughter of the mountain god was not to be easily subdued as her waters darted about uncontrollably. Only Shiva could tame her by entangling her in the coils of his hair. When her waters could finally wriggle their way out, they were calmer and purer. They turned arid wastes alive and filled up the oceans. Since those ancient times when King Bhagiratha sought her help, Ganga, whether roaring or placid, dancing or sombre, continues to enchant one and all with her incomparable beauty."
Subtitle, series and summary from 2009 printing.

95.heading: Taming.
95.title: "Surya : How the Sun God was Tamed"
95.author: script, Mahay Balse ; illustrations, Ram Waeerkar ; editor, Anant Pai
95.appears_in: 31 p. in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 566 (1974, 2010 printing).
notes: (Epics & Mythology)
Begins: "Vishwakarma, the cosmic architect, had a daughter called Sanjna."

Summary from back cover: "Sanjna basked in the warmth of her husband, the radiant Sun God, Surya. But sometimes, the sun's glare got uncomfortably fierce, and Sanjna could not bear it. She devised the perfect cover for herself: Chhaya, her mirror image! Away from the blazing Surya, the lonely Sanjna pined for her beloved. Eventually, a way had to be found to ensure everyone's happiness."

Summary (from OCLC): When four students, Jake, Chris, Tammy, and Tommy, get lost during a field trip to the Rooty Tooty Toy Company, they're followed home by four military robots, Skye, Rock, Aqua, and Wind. Now, the owner of the Rooty Tooty Toy Company wants his robots back and he's willing to do anything to get them!

142.heading: Tamsin.
142.title: Roots
142.author: by Andi Watson.
notes: 1 v. : ill. ; 26 cm.
(Skeleton Key ; 5)
"Collecting issues 1-4 of the Roots mini-series."

Back cover blurb: "Times are a changin' in Garfield. Tamsin begins to consider her future plans for college. Only there's one thing standing in her way...her best friend Kitsune. How can she leave her behind when Kitty can't even shop for groceries on her own. Community college beckons, but is it really what Tamsin wants?"

146.heading: Tamura, Yumi.
146.title: Basara
146.author: story and art by Yumi Tamura ; English adaptation by Gerard Jones.
notes: (Viz Graphic Novel)

Summary (from OCLC): A story about a girl, Sarasa, the leader of a small community of people in Japan, sometime after the collapse of material culture at the end of Twentieth century. She has decided to fight with the rival clan to revenge her killed brother. However, she falls in love with her enemy's son.
Previously published in Japan by Shogakukan, Inc., 1991.

Summary (from OCLC): A story about a girl, Sarasa, the leader of a small community of people in Japan some time after the collapse of material culture at the end of the twentieth century. She has decided to fight with the rival clan to revenge her killed brother. However, she falls in love with her enemy's son.
